normalised: **Environmental News: Wildlife Conservation Efforts Intensify in the Sundarbans**

unnormalised: **Environmental News: Wildlife Conservation Efforts Intensify in the Sundarbans**
normalised: Kolkata, West Bengal - Renewed efforts are underway to bolster wildlife conservation in the Indian Sundarbans, home to the Royal Bengal Tiger. Doctor Anjali Sharma, Director of the West Bengal Forest Department, announced increased funding for anti-poaching measures.

unnormalised: Kolkata, West Bengal - Renewed efforts are underway to bolster wildlife conservation in the Indian Sundarbans, home to the Royal Bengal Tiger. Dr. Anjali Sharma, Director of the West Bengal Forest Department, announced increased funding for anti-poaching measures.
normalised: The initiative includes deploying more forest guards and equipping them with advanced surveillance technology. Approximately rupee fifty lakhs has been allocated for habitat restoration, focusing on mangrove reforestation across ten square kilometer.

unnormalised: The initiative includes deploying more forest guards and equipping them with advanced surveillance technology. Approximately Rs. 50 Lakhs has been allocated for habitat restoration, focusing on mangrove reforestation across 10 sq km.
normalised: The Wildlife Institute of India (W I I) is collaborating on a tiger census using camera traps, expected to provide critical data by December two thousand and twenty four. Local communities are also being integrated into conservation programs through eco-tourism initiatives, fostering a sense of ownership and responsibility towards protecting the fragile ecosystem. A recent workshop highlighted the importance of preserving the Sundarbans' biodiversity, not just for the tiger, but for all its inhabitants, from the estuarine crocodile to the diverse avian population. The preservation of this U N E S C O world heritage site remains a national priority.

unnormalised: The Wildlife Institute of India (WII) is collaborating on a tiger census using camera traps, expected to provide critical data by December 2024. Local communities are also being integrated into conservation programs through eco-tourism initiatives, fostering a sense of ownership and responsibility towards protecting the fragile ecosystem. A recent workshop highlighted the importance of preserving the Sundarbans' biodiversity, not just for the tiger, but for all its inhabitants, from the estuarine crocodile to the diverse avian population. The preservation of this UNESCO world heritage site remains a national priority.
